Review: Note: This is specific to the Q35 headset with the most advanced sound and mic processing available in this headset line (in case it is mixed in with other Anker Soundcore headsets).SUMMARYOverall, this is a good - even great - bluetooth headset. But for meetings, missing a few critical items such as good low battery reporting, and especially a mic mute button on the headset really mar an otherwise great product. The gimmicky auto-pause feature should be off by default until it's ready for primetime and out of alpha/beta stage, made even worse by taking hours to get the app installed to turn it off. Furthermore the standard of being able to easily connect to two devices is not met here - you have to manually reconnect the 2nd device from bluetooth settings. If this headset was $50 I could still give it 4-5 stars for the value, but as a meeting headset, at this price, I give it 3 stars as the headset and app software currently stand.I really, really want to like this headset. It is a very good bluetooth headset in general, but for meetings/calls, there are some issues. For general music/audio playback, I gave it 5 stars on sound quality, and the controls are fine for that with both playback pause and volume up/down, plus different ways to swap between noise cancellation modes. All that works great, as advertised. The rest of the review will cover primairly headset usage.PROS:- The sound in general is good, with good noise cancellation. The "transparent" noise cancellation mode lets you hear everything around you well.- The sound processing of voice without a boom mic works great, with good noise cancellation of background noise such as typing, eating/drinking, TV in the background, etc. significantly or completely reduced. This works better than I expected - about as good as I was hoping.- The battery life is amazing. I haven't directly measured, but it feels like the claim of 40 hours with NC on is correct. See below on reporting though.- Connection distance of the bluetooth is great from my laptop. Definitely 50% to maybe 100% more than my other BT headsets. It's roughly 50-60 yards with a clear shot (from my front room out to the end of my driveway). I can go anywhere in my house, basement or 2nd floor, which isn't true of other headsets.- The over-the-ear setup and fit is decent overall (but see cons below). Do need to be a bit careful of it falling off in some situations.CONS:- My biggest con, and this takes away AT LEAST a full star. There is no mute button on the headset for the mic. This is just goofy to me. It's a bluetooth headset with an awesome no-boom mic voice pickup and great range. It's made for good calls/meetings - while roaming from your device. But no mic mute. In most conference calls (Teams/Zoom meetings, etc.), it is common practice to mute your mic when you are not talking. The entire purpose of a bluetooth headset is so that you can roam around when needed. That means I must have a mic button to mute/unmute myself when I'm away from my PC (or phone), directly on the headset. Whether I'm letting the dog out at my home (working remotely), grabbing a drink in the middle of a 2 hour call, or just walking around getting some steps in for the day during a call, I cannot afford to walk back to my PC to unmute. And if I'm unmuted, and the dog starts barking, or whatever, I need to be able to insta-mute from the headset. There are plenty of buttons, and maybe they could make a software update and allow you to configure this. I would happily give up the pause/play button for a mic mute button - or give up the NC mode button, given you can do that with the touch pad on the right ear as well.- This may only apply to fairly large heads (7 3/4" hat size) - while the headset is big enough for my big head, it still applies a decent amount of pressure on the ears, and the "heat up" effect is very noticeable after about 30 mins to an hour. I do not find it comfortable to wear these all day and take a break from them whenever possible during a long day of continuous meetings.- Finding the app and getting it installed (or getting an account setup and verified) was a significant ordeal. I have the Android app on my phone now, still no PC app (does one exist?). This is a significant stain on an otherwise stellar product. There should be a product page that clearly lays out exactly what software is available for each product, and if you are going to require an account (why must you?), and you are going to require verification, make sure the process works flawlessly.- For powering on/off you have to hold down the button for an extremely long period of time. I think it's over 5 seconds. This is very annoying. It should be 2-3 seconds, tops. This is especially important in needing a fast power-up time if someone calls and the headset is powered off, for example. I don't believe the power button has any other function built into it, so I can't imagine why this is tuned to such as long time. This could potentially be fixed in a firmware update, if Anker is listening...- The gimmicky "pause playback when you remove the headset" is alpha-level software at best. There are times this triggers just wearing the headset and I'm fighting with the headset hitting play to keep a video running while it's constantly being paused. Thankfully you can turn this behavior off in the app - if you can get the app setup...- Unfortunately when changing noise cancelling modes, they "announce" the new mode when you change, which cuts out the sound from your meeting, video, etc., to make the announcement, so you miss part of whatever you are listening to when changing the mode (for example, to hear what a colleague is trying to say to you with NC on). Maybe this can be turned off in the app?  If not, that would be a welcomed additional feature.- A hiccup on the battery life reporting - it goes from "high" upon powering up to "low" fairly soon (maybe after losing 20% or so?) and is in the "low" range for a very long time. Then you get a "beep" when battery is close to out. You get 2 or 3 beeps total, but I think it's less than 30 minutes before it shut down on me after the first beep. They really need a different setting for when you get to 15-20% of power (that should be "low"...), because that is where you should charge back to 80%+ for best battery longevity, and 30 minutes is not long enough advance warning when you can have 1-2 hour meetings. The first beep should be with maybe 5% of battery left (2-4 hours, given 40 total hours of battery), then make them progressively closer together as you get to 2%, 1%, 0.5%, "shutting off now", etc. Note that they do report the approximate battery level to my phone - perhaps you can get that in the PC app, if one exists and I can figure out where to download it from.- While you can pair the headset to 2 devices (e.g. laptop and phone), the device seems to only be able to connect to one of them at a time. This means you can't really switch to an incoming phone call from a meeting, for example. Or, even if you are just listening to a video or just have the headset on the desk, but connected to your PC, you can't pickup a phone call without opening your bluetooth settings on the phone and connecting. Then, to reconnect to the laptop, you need to open the bluetooth settings there and reconnect. I'm a little fuzzy on some of the details, since I've largely stopped using it for dual-purpose, but you may have to power the headset off and on again, then connect. This is all perhaps minor, but if you are going to advertise being able to work with 2 devices, it should work better than this.-FURTHER INFORMATION AND COMMENTS:Mic pickup and noise cancellation:I love the idea of using multiple mics (2) along with the other noise cancelling mics (4) in this headset to pick up voice from the user, and drown out other background noise - all without a boom mic! I tested this extensively by recording meetings in Microsoft Teams with just myself there, and tested the different teams noise cancellation modes along with this headset, while different noises were in the background - TV, typing on a quiet, but mechanical keyboard with different levels of intensity, and with different Teams noise cancellation settings.One thing for sure, do not use this headset and leave Teams on "auto" noise cancellation, or the "high" setting. Both of the noise cancellation algorithms together will create "too much" noise cancellation and drowned out your voice, causing semi-regular significant distortion when there is a moderate amount of background noise. Other people would complain that my volume sounded really low or that my voice was distorted, like there was a bad connection for a bit.I tested with the Teams NC set to "low" and "off". Low works well to add additional noise cancellation without adding additional distortion of my voice in my tests, and this is now the setting I've been using for a few weeks. This will drowned out light or moderate typing, myself eating and drinking, and all but fairly loud background noise. Setting Teams to "off" allows more to get through. You can start to hear moderate typing, for example (though it sounds very light, almost like small clicks). Either does a good job of reducing background noise while keeping the users voice in focus, without a boom mic present.

I've been shopping around for some decent LDAC enabled headphones to pair with my Fiio M6 audio device.  I previously bought the Edifier W820NB and they sounded quite decent for a lower-mid priced pair of headphones.  I had only heard of Edifier because I own a pair of their speakers, which I'm pretty happy with.  These were almost a keeper, but I decided to spend a bit more on something with more separation and crispness.I don't consider myself an audiophile by any means, but I'm all for spending a bit more for a clearer, more defined sound in my audio devices.  I have a friend who has a degree in audio engineering that always asks me why I spend more than I need to on my audio choices and I always ask him why he's so cheap with his.  I just always thought it was weird, considering his previously chosen profession.Anyway, I obviously had heard about the WF-1000XM4 and XM3 Sonys, but I wasn't sure I needed to drop that much money on headphones that I would only occasionally use.  Don't get me wrong, I love music, but generally, I'm listening to it on my turntable or in my car.  I just haven't found a pair of headphones that I'm comfortable wearing for hours at a time, these included.I read some other reviews about the comfort factor on these, and on that note, I was slightly disappointed, but not that surprised.  Maybe I have Elven ears and they just aren't made to house headphones for too long, I don't know.  Having said that, they're comfortable enough.  I didn't find myself fidgeting with the cups as much as I have others in the past.The box was well packaged and actually looked pretty fancy with a little sticker seal over some wax type looking paper to cover everything.  It comes with a USB-C charging cable, an airplane airline headphone adapter and a 3.5mm audio cable with volume control.  The 3.5mm cable seemed to be a little bit on the cheap side if I had to nitpick, but otherwise, it was fine.  I'd mostly be using it for the Bluetooth capabilities.  The case was pretty decent as well, although the plastic insert was kind of odd.  It looked like it was meant to stay in with the case, but it was so thin and cheaply made, that I have to think it was meant to be tossed.  It basically shows you how the headphone sits in the case and the reason why I think it was meant to be tossed is because under it, there's an etched drawing of how the headphones should sit in the case.  I'm getting the feeling people have tried to cram these headphones into their case in weird ways and end up complaining that they snap. :)Primarily, I listen to metal and all sub-genres of metal.  I almost bought some headphones called "Heavys" that were supposedly designed specifically for metal, but it was on a Kickstarter and I'm hesitant to go that route.  I'd rather wait to read reviews of it later after release and pay a little more if it's something I can't live without.  In the meantime, I wanted to try these as my brother bought me some Anker Liberty Neo earbuds a while back and I liked the quality of sound I was getting from them.  I'm not typically a fan of earbuds, though, so I use them sparingly.After charging the headphones to a full charge, I promptly booted them up, holding the power for 5 seconds to pair them with my Fiio.  It paired quickly with no issues and sounded an audible "boop."  I started playing a song.  I didn't have as much of an issue with the default preset sound as much as some others did, but I can also see how it wasn't everyone's cup of tea.After unsuccessfully trying to sideload the Soundcore app by copying the APK file to my Fiio (didn't seem to do anything when I tried to run it from the file manager), I decided to test out the multi-pair capabilities by pairing it with my phone to tweak the default preset.  While my test song was still playing, I double-tapped the power and successfully paired to my phone.  Unfortunately, as I was fiddling around, I bumped my hand on the headphones and it stopped the music.  I already knew that I would more than likely find the whole "pause your music detection" feature annoying.  I fidget and adjust the cups too much for this to be practical.  After the music stopped, I wasn't able to resume it and hear it playing for some reason.  It was paired to both my phone and the Fiio, it showed as playing, but no sound came out.I was fairly annoyed for the first few minutes of owning this thing, but I calmed myself, switched off the bluetooth on my devices, switched off the headphones and started over.  Then it worked fine.  I was able to load the "rock" preset and it stayed loaded after I unpaired with my phone.Even though my preferred genre of music is metal, I also listen to others, so I ran it through a battery of FLAC files ranging from Halsey/Clairo/Eilish/Adele/Juice WRLD/Led Zeppelin/Rush/As I Lay Dying/Heaven Shall Burn/Behemoth, etc.  Everything sounded excellent.  There was enough instrument separation, crispness and clarity for all of the different genres for me to consider this an acceptable pair of headphones for my every day use.  Will I eventually "upgrade" to the XM4's?  Maybe some day, but these were plenty suitable for my mildly discerning ears for now.Except for the weird little glitch where I didn't hear anything the first few minutes I messed with it, it's been perfect.  Honestly, it may not have been a good idea to still have a song playing while pairing another device and then accidentally activating the "headset off detection" feature.  About that... I read a few reviews stating that the same feature on the XM4's was a little sensitive as well.  Maybe this feature is not ready for prime-time just yet.  Not until we have a better way to adjust it?  I was thinking that if you can have the app adjust it, maybe you put on the headphones and tap something that shows it's firmly on your head.  Then, if there were a way that it would measure the distance between the cups and enable the pause when a certain measurement goes beyond that distance, MAYBE that would work. Not just when it shifts on your head, but when it detects both cups being pulled away from the ears.I'm more annoyed having my music be constantly interrupted than I am with having to press the pause button from time to time.  I mean, I'm as lazy as the next person, but c'mon.. do we really need this weird feature?

I am a giant Anker fan. I have owned their cords and cables for years as they have always been high quality items at reasonable prices. A few years back, Anker branded their speakers and headphones under the Soundcore label. Soundcore follows in the footsteps of their parent company in making really high quality stuff at a great price point. These Q35's, while not as inexpensive as their prior models, are simply amazing. These are the first Soundcore headphones to offer the LDAC Sony codec which makes them capable of HiFi less compressed sound. You will be able to take advantage of listening to Spotify on the very high quality setting or, better yet, really hear Tidal Masters the way they are meant to be heard. I am not a giant over ear guy. I have a ton of ear buds. My wife has the world class Sony WH-1000XM3's which I have traveled with a great deal. I owned the Soundcore Q30s for a few days, loved them, and gave them to my oldest who was whining that he needed a pair. I currently own the Microsoft Surface 2s that I got primarily for working from home. Love them but the sound is just average for music. So, enter the new Q35's. I have had these about a week. Here is the breakdown:-Sound / App: It is amazing. One of the reviews complained about sounding muddy. I am no audiophile but I just don't hear that here. These are crisp and vibrant sounding. Yes, Soundcore does tune these to emphasize the low end a bit. They come preset to the "Soundcore Signature" profile. However, Souncore gives you a very robust app to work with. Just get in there and tune these to your liking. You can use one of their many presets or make your own custom sound. When you get these going with a high quality stream, at the risk of sounding overly dramatic, it is breathtaking. Listening to The National, The Eagles, and Metallica on Tidal all just sound incredible. Great lows, full mids, crisp highs, all of which are nicely separated and balanced. Beautiful to listen to. Also, when watching video there is zero discernible latency. Voices match what you are watching. Well done.-Battery life / Connectivity: Really as good as it gets. 40 hours or so with ANC on and 60 hours without. Just about best in class. Bluetooth 5.0 is here so easy pairing and rock solid range and stable connection.-Active Noise Cancellation: If there is an area to ding these, it is here. The ANC is good. Soundcore has been steadily improving in this arena for some time. It is not Sony / Bose good. However, for most, I believe this ANC will be more than fine. It should handle planes and traveling. The only things that really get through are sudden high frequency sounds. Again, overall good, but just not as spectacular as everything else Soundcore offers here.-Form Factor / Controls: The Q35's build is outstanding. They feel great in your hands. Not like $129 headphones should feel. I feel no discernible difference in quality from the Sony headphones. The controls are handled via physical buttons on the right can. The left can has power and the ANC toggle. One nice feature that Soundcore borrowed from Sony is that you can enter transparency by simply resting your hand over the right can. It's great! Something new I love is autopause. All my buds have this but I have never seen over ears use this. Simply slide a cup off of either ear and whatever you are listening to pauses. It is really helpful. My son walked up to me and began speaking. I didnt miss anything he said and didn't need to worry about pausing my content. Great addition! Soundcore also gives your a 3.5mm audio cable if you want to go wired. I haven't tried it here yet but it worked great on the Q30's.-Call Quality: The Q30's were nothing special with how they handled calls. The Q35's still aren't special but seem to be vastly improved. They have added an AI algorithm to the beam forming mics that seems to be more effective at isolating your voice especially in loud environments. I still get too much wind noise when outside but calls are solid and very capable here overall.I will update as I go here. For $129, Soundcore is offering you a tremendous value proposition. HiFi sound, good ANC, great battery, and tremendous build quality. If High Fidelity sound isn't your bag, get the Q30's. Same build, same ANC, and same great app, for about half the price. However, if you want to really hear music buy these, find some uncompressed (or less compressed) music, and enjoy. It really is something you need to hear.*Update* I have really been pounding these and didn't really say anything about comfort. They are lightweight and very comfortable for long term wear. I am a hot guy (sweaty not physically) by nature and these are warm but overly hot like so many over ears I have worn. I have had them on now for about two hours tonight. All good. I am warm in there but not too much so. Solid.***Update for later model Samsung users***So one really important note I just figured out thanks to testing the new B&W PI7's is that you really want to make sure you have HD Audio (in this case, LDAC) enabled on your device. Samsung actually deactivates it by default. If you go in to developer options, you can turn it on. Go to "about phone", go to "software options", and find your Android build number. Tap on that 7 times. Back out and go to "developer options." Connect your Q35's to your phone (or any LDAC capable headset) and then scroll down in developer options and you should see an HD Audio button. Slide that over to activate it and it should automatically connect to your highest possible streaming option that headphone offers. Don't worry, you will not hurt anything here. Get your Tidal account going or move your Spotify quality to "very high" and you will be off to the races. Game changer for me and my S21 Ultra!

Well, the sound quality is excelent, but the mic on it is so bad... also, the range of connection is sooooo SMALL, when i walk to my living room (aprox. 15 meters away from my laptop where the headphones are connected) the audio starts to cut or glitch. And i get it, but apart from stopping the audio, it creates a loud sound and it's so annoying. I use this headphone to connect to PC and Phone at the same time. on PC is for watching movie and meeting. Connection on Phone is for Hand free receiving call.Sound quality and ANC are working well for me. I use it in office environment. It help to suppress people talking noise. Microphone has good sensitivity. I don't need to speak loudly but need to remember to keep it mute when not talking.Built quality is OK. I found some imperfection spots on ear cushion. It is just uneven seam.The biggest issue of this headphone is at connection with 2 host devices at the same time. When it power up, it connect to only one of the host. It seems to be randomly connect to either Phone or PC. Connecting the second one is tricky. If it connected to Phone, Connect to PC will need Phone to turn off Bluetooth. After PC is connected Phone and turn on Bluetooth and phone will connect. The other case that it connect to PC first is harder to fix. It have to turn the headphone off and on.Wearing detection  does not work consistently. When it works, there are several seconds delay after take off from my ears. I think power button has only function to turn on/off. My previous headphone use power button as battery level checker when short press. Quick Transparency mode(touch on right side ear cup) is toggle on/off. In my opinion, it should be on when touch and automatically when stop touching.

I have been trialing these headphones for the last three weeks. They aren’t the best, but for the price, you could do much worse.The ear covers are not the most comfortable, but far from the worst. By the type of material, I don’t expect them to last forever, but they are easy to clean and wipe down after working out or sharing.The quality of the sound is great, using it in my iPhone 12 Pro Max, Nintendo Switch, and 2018 MacBook Pro. I have used both the plug in option as well as the wireless, and both work fantastic. I have not used the plug in option during a phone call, simply out of ease of using them totally wireless. Some of my friends have said they can hear me much better without them, but I think any hands free device (headphones, earpieces, etc) that distance the microphone from right next to your face seem to lessen the quality. Noise cancelling, however, is 10/10, as is transparency. I typically use them in “regular” mode.The battery life is also impressive. I have fallen asleep wearing these, woken up, tossed them aside (sometimes forgetting to turn them off) and come back later after work to find they are still alive and working fine. A quick charge every once and a while, when I remember to plug them in, and they keep going without issues. I have yet to run them all the way dead.Overall, I am very happy with my purchase. Hopefully when the ear covers wear down, I can replace them with something of a higher quality. Otherwise, great headphones and hard to beat for the price.

I use these primarily for work. This means a ton of confrence calls and music while I am working on things.  I have asked multiple people how I sound now thatbi am using these for my conference calls and they say they can hear me very well.  The noise cancelation and transpancy modes are great.  The microphone also does a good job of noise filtering too.  People I am on a call with don't hear the kids in the background or me typing.Tha audio on my end is great too.  I can hear every very clearly.  Music sounds great.  They are very comfortable to wear for most of a work day too.  They hold their charge very well.Negative- the headphones are hit or miss at being connected to two devices (my phone and my laptop). This is one of the perks of these headphones that made me purchase these ones.  If you use the sound core app to manipulate the transparency/noise cancelation then it kills the audio completely for the laptop. I find myself having to turn Bluetooth off on my phone to ensure I have a streamlined expirence using them for my laptop, which is not ideal but its not a deal breaker either.Overall I would recommend, with the understanding of the dual device limitations.

Very happy. I'm not comparing these to the most expensive/highest rated known brand models, only what I'd consider the competition's "mid" level.  I wear these in an environment where they are not handled with kid gloves...  This is the 3rd set of ANC over the ear headphones I've tried over time (MPOW & Sony were the other brands).These outperformed a set of Sony WH-CH710N I received in:Sound Quality- much better as you can personalize it with the equalizer/appANC - way better, probably twice as effective as the Sony in the environment I use themBuild - seem/feel better built than the Sony model I hadComfort - softer material on the ear cushions, better seal around the ears too for meI mainly wear these in a heavy low-frequency motor noise environment (hours spent in ag equipment). Comfortable even after many hours.  The ANC is the most important function to me to drown out the low engine drone. It doesn't eliminate it 100%, but helps tremendously so that I don't feel like my head is humming after a long time spent in the cab.I don't like adding apps to my phone normally, but the app here is simple/straight fwd where you can change the equalizer settings to your liking, plus change the ANC response based on 3 environments. Even has an option to pipe "soothing" sounds (birds chirping, water running, etc) if you want to for relaxation.As far as using it for phone calls, callers on the other end said they could understand me fine... I'm not on the phone much though when using them.I actually like the physical buttons on the headphone to control it rather than supposed intuitive swipes/sensors/proximity gestures that some manufacturers think are cool just because they can do it.  Didn't take long to use these control buttons without any frustration of trying to find them...I'm not getting paid for this as some reviews admit... Just trying to help someone else that may want something for a similar situation.I will edit this review if my experience changes.

Comfort and Fit:This product is very comfortable yet will fall of your head VERY easily if you try exercising with them (or even just bending down to pick something up). I tried using these for the gym and ultimately I just would not recommend. These are perfect for watching movies and sitting/laying somewhere. You could go on walks with these with no issues but running/weight lifting (primarily deadlifting and any exercise that consists of a lot of movement) on will make this a challenge to keep on your head.  Comfort is a 10/10, never get tired of wearing these and never get any discomfort. Fit is a 6/10 for how loose the headphones feel almost always and I have a pretty large head so I'd expect it to fit more tightly on me.Noise Cancelation and Transparency Mode:Noise Cancelation on these are pretty good. They for sure block out a lot of background noise and when you're listening to music, there's rarely noises that will break through. 8/10 rating for that. The transparency mode amplifies the noises around you very well and is useful when talking to people around you. 9/10 rating.Sound Quality:AMAZING sound quality. I feel as if I'm in a theater whenever I watch movies and listen to music. You can hear every little detail thrown at you. Truly worth the money for the sound quality. The only downside is there can be a lot of adjusting to make these sound amazing. I spent SOOO much time adjusting these to make them sound just as I wanted them to sound. The soundcore app just has so many different options for EQ settings that it can be a hassle finding the right one, especially if you're nitpicky (like me haha). For those wondering, I'd recommend the acoustic, piano, flat, or your own personalized EQ setting when you get the chance to customize this set of headphones. 9/10 for sound quality.Volume Control:The controls as shown in the photos I've included look simplistic yet they can be hard to remember which is which when using them while being worn. I have had these for a few months and still can't entirely remember the controls all the time. The touch controls as well as the headphones ability to stop the music/video once you take off the headphones is annoying. Had to be turned off. It's hit or miss with it for it simply doesn't work all the time. The touch controls also had to be turned off. Just found the button for NC was easier to click to change modes.Overall, I'd say these are a great set of headphones yet there are some flaws. The battery life is amazinggg and the quick charge feature is great. If you want a pair of headphones for relaxing and not exercising, these are for you!

I bought  the Q35 after reading the reviews on Amazon.  My JBL E65BNCT head phone left ear hinge-pin keeper broke and JBL does not sell the hing-pin keeper (looks to be a 10 cent molded plastic snap in detail - shame on JBL).  I find the  Q35 ANC to be inferior to the JBL E65BTNC.  The only way I could test this is to back away from a kitchen sink with the water faucet running at full flow.  The E65BNCT ambient level (ANC on, no sound app playing) became silent at 9 feet back from the sink.  The Q35 became silent at 13 feet back from the sink. None of the ANC profiles (Transport, indoor, or outdoor) changed the 13 foot subjective distance from the running faucet.I like the ear-piece hing on the Q35. It appears to be more substantial then the hing on the E65BTNC.  The Q35 comes with a substantial storage/travel case that should protect the Q35 when taken on vacation.  The E65BTNC had a soft draw-string bag that offered no protection and requires you to carefully fold the ear-pieces to slip the unit into the bag.The Q35 head-band is not tight: I doubt that you could wear the Q35 while working out on a tread-mill or out jogging (two activities I avoid and have not tested).When wearing the Q35 in bed, I position the head band over my forehead.  That works well but if the head band is not touching my forehead and I get up from bed, the Q35 can slip and is in danger of falling off.I have turned off the sense function that pauses audio if the Q35 is removed from your head.  I found video and audio sources being paused annoyingly without removing the Q35 from my head requiring me to press play on the iPad to resume.When I first turn on the Q35 and start a YouTube video on my iPad mini6, the sound blares in my ears until I touch either of the volume buttons on the iPad.

My old skull candy hesh 2, started acting up and I really did not love the way they fit my ears, sort of on the ear instead of around it. Sound was ok, but it was time for the upgrade.  I never heard of soundcore or their products but decided to try them not expecting much.  They new headphones arrived in a nice hard case, with all the necessary cables etc.  When I first heard them I was blown away. They also fit my head and big ears suprising very well.  They also have a sensor in them that turns off the sound when you take them off.  Very cool idea.My only gripe are small control buttons.  I wish they were more pronounced and distinguishable.

These sound fantastic. Amazing for getting work done in your own world in public spaces or drowning out distracting home office noises or just listening to audiobooks or music while cooking or doing chores. They drop out the background noise floor very effectively so you can listen at a low volume level and preserve your hearing while experiencing subtle details.Some people complained about the smell in other reviews. I have a very sensitive nose and am very cautious about off-gassing, and these had no smell problem at all.I was a little disappointed initially as I learned that bluetooth degrades the audio quality for calls (it has to split the same amount of bandwidth for two audio streams - your voice and the incoming audio - so it halves the quality). But there are workarounds if that bothers you when on calls. 1) use the headphones in wired mode with in-line mic, 2) remain wireless but just use the internal microphone of your laptop or phone if the app allows input device selection that's different from the output, 3) keep the headphones in wireless mode, but plug a $5 lavalier mic into your laptop and clip it onto your shirt 4) just deal with the degraded audio for the duration of the wireless call. IMPORTANT NOTE: after the wireless call is over you may have to manually switch the input back to internal microphone to get your high-quality wireless audio back. This happened to me with MacOS.The 2 device connectivity (Android phone and Macbook) has been pretty good. Sometimes I have to manually tell it to reconnect to my laptop or phone when I turn them on, sometimes it connects automatically. It's a minor inconvenience. To switch between the two devices you pause the audio on the current device and then start playing some audio on the other device. Sometimes I have to press pause and play a couple of times before it switches, but it's no big deal. It never will play both simultaneously. It's one or the other.The battery life has been phenomenal.All in all I'm thrilled with the value here and the huge upgrade that these are for my productivity and listening enjoyment. I also believe that they will help save my hearing in the long run by allowing me to keep the volume low while still hearing all the details.

The Soundcore Life Q35s are an insanely good deal for the price point. I was looking for a set of Bluetooth cans that support LDAC without having to shell out some serious cash on the Sony WH-1000s.The sound quality is fantastic. I've noticed some reviews mentioning the loud bass. The default EQ is indeed quite bass heavy but the Soundcore app features a large selection of EQ presets as well as custom capability. After some browsing and tinkering I created a custom EQ that sounds exactly right, with some of the sub bass rolled off and 100-200 Hz boosted for some good punch. The thing is the Q35s are capable of reproducing bass at many different frequencies, instead of just that generic muddy boom bass that you hear in Beats or cheap brands. The key is to find an EQ that balances those bass frequencies to your liking. Beyond that the mids have wonderful presence and an immersive soundstage. They remain wonderfully distinct from the bass frequencies. Treble is clear and detailed without fatiguing the ears. The high frequencies are pushed behind the mids to create the perfect balance of clarity and softness. I think Boss does this slightly better but Boss doesn't feature LDAC as a Bluetooth option. When LDAC is engaged on the Q35s the sound is hard to believe for wireless.I don't take my Q35s out of my apartment but for inside use the ANC works perfect. The hum of my swamp cooler, fans, or any low ambient sound is almost totally muted. I've heard the ANC falls short when used out in public and that the Sony WH-1000s are better. That wouldn't surprise me, they're nearly three times the price of the Q35s. But for normal indoor use the ANC is great.Battery life is insane. I charge them a few times a week (I'm neurotic about having full charged batteries, total OCD) but everything I do they're already at 70-80%. I basically top them off every couple days for an hour or so and literally never worry about running out of battery. I could be lost in the woods for a week and these things would last the whole time, probably outlive me. The build quality is awesome too. I'm not worried about these things snapping or cracking and the lack of a cord means I also don't have to worry about snagging the cord on a doorknob and having them violently hurled across the room right before the best part of the song hits. That was the absolute worst.If you're phone supports LDAC I can't recommend these enough, some of the best money I've ever spent.

Okay, this review is for the Anker Soundcore Q35 headphones. I am pairing them with my Samsung A71 smartphone using Amazon HD music service.Wow....These headphones exceeded my expectations. I have ignored bluetooth headphones for quite a few years now, being that I kept hearing about significant sound quality degradation as compared to wired headphones.My previous headphone "rig" was an Ipod, then my smartphone at the time (when services like Spotify more or less made streaming the main way of listening to music) , coupled with a 300.00 separate headphone amp. So, I would be relaxing on the couch or lying in bed with the following: my smartphone connected to about a 1 foot cable, which was then connected to my headphone amp input, then the headphone cable connected to my headphone amp output. Cluttered and complicated but...oh, the sound was so fine. I used pretty nice headphones such as the AKG 701s, and the Audio-technica ATH-M50X.Enter the Soundcore Q35 headphones with LDAC codec. I think this is the key. I am no audiophile, nor do I have "trained" ears claiming such.However, I'm pleased to say that with just my Smartphone, and these new Soundcore Q35's, the sound coming into my ears are just as good or perhaps better than my previous cluttered wired setup!LDAC coded? I'm no technical wizard but from what I understand, this is the highest quality way in which to stream your music, and its worth your while to use LDAC if you purchase these headphones. Don't automatically assume LDAC is going to stream once you pair your new headphones to your smartphone.There are YOUTUBE videos that show you how to go into developer mode (very easy) and enable LDAC.The whole process took me 5 minutes or less.So, the combination of Amazon HD music and the LDAC codec enabled is a winning combination for sound quality. Oh, and if you're a Prime member and subscribe to Amazon music for 7.99 a month, you can now activate Amazon HD music for no extra cost, just go into your settings. A no brainer.The bottom line: My Samsung A71 phone with LDAC codec enabled, Amazon HD music, and these new Anker Soundcore Q35 headphones produce the same or even  better sounding music to my ears then my old complicated wired rig! I would give these headphones 6 stars if I could.***Update as of November 6, 2022***Okay,  I still love these headphones after owning them over a year.  I bought the new Sony XM5 headphones when they were discounted down to 348.00I love these new Sony headphones but what's interesting is I'm still putting on and listening to my Anker Q35s and am still blown away by the sound.  Conclusion? I really wanted to like these headphones, and I splurged the extra $50 over the Q30 even though I primarily exist in the Apple ecosphere and I knew LDAC wouldn't do anything for me, thinking a newer generation gives fewer opportunities for bugs and kinks. I think they still aren't fully cooked yet, and I don't want to wait on firmware to get it sorted out, so sadly I'm sending them back.The good: The build quality is great. All the materials seem top-rate. The metal headband is a very nice anodized looking brushed material. All the plastics look and feel upscale and solid, not cheap at all. The ear cups have good memory foam and are extremely comfortable to wear. The head padding is a different, more traditional-feeling foam material, but cushions quite well. The extra EQ functionality in the app is an appreciated feature, and it's not hard to get bass, mids, and trebles dialed in to your liking. I didn't love any of the preset EQ settings, and many of them sound pretty hollow to me, but that's fairly easily overcome if you don't mind tweaking with the equalizer for a while. Took about 20 minutes total, and half a dozen different styles of songs to find settings I really liked.The carrying case is a nice touch, though I don't imagine I'd ever use it. If that's something that might sway your consideration, be aware it's a solid and nicely done addition. The packaging, if you care, all seems very premium. I didn't spend a ton of time with the controls on the phones themselves, but they also feel solid, though not without some serious issues I will mention below.Overall, this feels like a really well done and an extremely affordable option that doesn't feel cheap in any way.BUT....The bad: I could ignore the Dollar Store Beats looking logo if they performed better than they do. When the sound is good, as I said, it's great. If only it would stay that way. I have been using these for work calls, just to get used to sound and mic quality. At first I was happy. No one shared negative feedback on the mic quality so I assume it is fine, but the sound on my end kept jumping back and forth from normal to sounding like I was talking to mid-80s robots. I was able to temporarily fix it by disconnecting and reconnecting the headphones, but that simply isn't a realistic long-term option for me.While out walking the dog, I had the headphones stop playing my podcast on my iPhone several times. It happened a couple of times when I was adjusting the volume and mode settings, where it would just stop and I had to restart. It also did it on its own a few times, with no obvious outside stimulus. I have NEVER had a problem with this with any other earphone I've used. Even cheap ones, which these are not.I didn't find the ANC anything to be wild about. In fairness it's not the primary reason I bought these, but if I were to have been seeking it out, I have no doubt I'd be extremely disappointed. I walk on a fairly heavily trafficked road and the car noise between ANC and normal was barely noticeable. It's mostly like someone turned down the background volume a little bit and then dropped some light white noise on it. Maybe that's what people expect out of ANC, but I wasn't wowed by it at all.Also, I found the Wearing Detection feature to be inconsistent, and it only seemed to work about half the time. When it did work, it took a good 3-5 seconds to pause. The rest of the time, it just kept playing, or would restart shortly after pausing. Not a primary feature that drove my purchase, bit if it's going to have it, it should work right.So in summary, I think there is probably a really good headphone in here trying to work its way out, but I am entirely underwhelmed by the product they brought to market. It all feels very much like it needs a few more months to hammer out software issues. In fairness, I have no doubt, because it's newish and because it's a flagship product, they'll release firmware updates to address many of my concerns. I just don't like paying full price to beta test.I rated these a two, but they're likely more like a 2.5. An eventually really good product that needs work. I will be returning them. Hopefully the Liberty 3 Pros that are charging on my desk at the time of writing turn out to be a little more well done while I continue to look for over-the-ear wireless headphones I really feel good about keeping. For the most part, I am a fan of Anker and Soundcore, and I have several of their products. This one just misses the mark for me.

I have ignored bluetooth headphones for quite a few years now, being that I kept hearing about significant sound quality degradation as compared to wired headphones.My previous headphone "rig" was an Ipod, then my smartphone at the time (when services like Spotify more or less made streaming the main way of listening to music) , coupled with a 300.00 separate headphone amp. So, I would be relaxing on the couch or lying in bed with the following: my smartphone connected to about a 1 foot cable, which was then connected to my headphone amp input, then the headphone cable connected to my headphone amp output. Cluttered and complicated but...oh, the sound was so fine. I used pretty nice headphones such as the AKG 701s, and the Audio-technica ATH-M50X.Enter the Soundcore Q35 headphones with LDAC codec. I think this is the key. I am no audiophile, nor do I have "trained" ears claiming such.However, I'm pleased to say that with just my Smartphone, and these new Soundcore Q35's, the sound coming into my ears are just as good or perhaps better than my previous cluttered wired setup!LDAC coded? I'm no technical wizard but from what I understand, this is the highest quality way in which to stream your music, and its worth your while to use LDAC if you purchase these headphones. Don't automatically assume LDAC is going to stream once you pair your new headphones to your smartphone.There are YOUTUBE videos that show you how to go into developer mode (very easy) and enable LDAC.The whole process took me 5 minutes or less.So, the combination of Amazon HD music and the LDAC codec enabled is a winning combination for sound quality. Oh, and if you're a Prime member and subscribe to Amazon music for 7.99 a month, you can now activate Amazon HD music for no extra cost, just go into your settings. A no brainer.The bottom line: My Samsung A71 phone with LDAC codec enabled, Amazon HD music, and these new Anker Soundcore Q35 headphones produce the same or even  better sounding music to my ears then my old complicated wired rig! I would give these headphones 6 stars if I could.***Update as of November 6, 2022***Okay,  I still love these headphones after owning them over a year.  I bought the new Sony XM5 headphones when they were discounted down to 348.00I love these new Sony headphones but what's interesting is I'm still putting on and listening to my Anker Q35s and am still blown away by the sound.  Conclusion? If you're on a budget I really recommend these Q35s as they may sound as good as the Sony XM5s at less than third the price.I think? the Sonys sound a little better but honestly not sure as it's so close.Bottom line: these are a steal for the sound you're getting.  Oh, last thing.  If you have an Android phone,  learn how to activate the LDAC codec as I mentioned earlier in original review.  YouTube or Google should give instructions (easy) on how to do it. The upgrade in sound is worth it.

I was introduced to Soundcore with the Life Q10, an upper budget tier headset that had an amazing battery, decent sound and fussy wireless connectivity.  When the Q35 brought the brand out of the budget tier, I considered its positive reviews reason enough to give it a shot.  They've certainly doubled down on their strengths, with another amazing battery, even better sound and somehow worse wireless connectivity.I'd really be shocked if Anker couldn't do a headset with a decent battery life.  While I don't want to underplay just how market leading they are in this area, I've come to expect this from them and won't dwell on it.The sound quality is solid for the price.  Soundcore products have a certain affinity for bass, which holds true for the Q35 too.  I was nonetheless pleased with the overall sound separation and clarity.  I toyed with the Soundcore app's accompanying EQ, but ultimately felt the hardware was usually at its best with its defaults, letting it be its bassy self shine through.I'm really close to abandoning the bluetooth connectivity entirely, and am glad it has 3.5mm to fall back on.  Of the first 5 devices I tried to connect to the Q35, only one accepted it on the first try.  Most took a double-digit number of attempts to pair.  Periodic disconnects have been common, even at an arms reach away across open air.  Bluetooth Multipoint is a feature in name only, as there's no convenient way to toggle between connected devices.  When it does switch devices, it'll sometimes jump to max volume and blast your ears out.  Bluetooth is a garbage standard and I hate that we live in the darker timeline where it somehow became the protocol of choice, so I can't fully blame Anker.  But as things are, this just isn't a reliable product.  Maybe firmware updates will improve this down the line, which is thankfully an option through the Soundcore app.The active noise cancellation is above average.  While the amount of noise it eliminates isn't significant, I give it extra acknowledgement for accomplishing it without a tight fit or obnoxious hissing.  The ANC system is operated by one button that cycles through "Normal" (off), "Noise Cancelling" (on) and "Transparency" (instead amplifies noise to simulate wearing an open-backed headset).  Each press of the button has a voice announce the mode it switched to, which makes going through them sluggish and disruptive to the listening experience.  "Transparency" is slightly more accessible in that you can rest your hand on the right ear cup to toggle between it and your other most recent ANC mode, though it still does so with the obtrusive narrator and is prone to accidental activation.  An ordinary switch would've been much preferred.Another feature the Q35 touts is a sensor that pauses your media when you remove the headset.  This is the kind of feature where the convenience can be rapidly overshadowed if it doesn't work right.  I'm sad to say it really does not work.  Listening from a stationary, upright position resulting in frequent false pauses.  It was infuriating and I ultimately turned it off in the Soundcore app.  An interesting idea very poorly implemented.As for comfort, the headset has large, soft cups and a very loose fit.  I found it fairly easy to wear for extended periods of time.  Though the loose fit does make it a less ideal choice for vigorous activity, and they can easily fall off when bending over or the like.I'll be keeping the headset, but I'm nonetheless disappointed in its shortcomings.  Here's hoping some of it is improved with firmware or in the next iteration.

I bought these Q35s for my wife as an experiment after buying THREE pair of Sony XM4s (for me, my mom and my daughter).  So I spent nearly $900 on the Sony's!!!  I wanted to see if these Q35s were at all comparable to the XM4s since they cost less than half of what the Sony's cost.  Much to my surprise (and perhaps dismay) the Q35s kept pace with the Sony's in just about every way except maybe noise cancelling.  And this is not to suggest that the ANC on the Q35s is not good...it IS good...certainly good enough for what most people are looking for.  The Sony's really have just about the best ANC tech on the market in the <$500 range.  That said, you won't miss the difference at all unless you happen to be an XM4 user also.  From a sound quality standpoint, the Q35s are definitely more BASS biased than the Sony's...but it's a fantastically CLEAN bass not a muddy annoying bass like so many other headphones on the market.  In fact, if your preferred music genres include Pop, EDM, hip-hop...anything with prominent bass and/or sub-bass...the Q35s will blow your mind.  The Sony XM4 offers a more 'balanced' frequency reproduction across the board and ARE extremely good.  But I think for MOST people, the Q35s are the obvious choice.  You're not only likely to prefer the default sound profile of the Q35s (and the phone app is also excellent, giving you all the EQ custom settings and presets you'd ever want), but you'll save $150 without sacrificing anything that you'd really miss vs buying the Sony's.  5 stars and 2 thumbs up!

OLD version was 01.11.01.18 fixed all of the LDAC issues except I heard a few - very few- pauses on the Fiio M15..it has two LDAC settings: 1) LDAC - Quality priority mode and 2) LDAC - Normal mode. The Normal mode was fine but the noises were on the Priority mode. I decided to give it some time ..and at this point the LDAC Quality mode appears to be - sound - fine.So, my review is less about the actual sound properties of the phones..with which I am very happy .. and more about the support I received from Soundcore/Anker. They went way beyond the call of duty in supporting me in timely fashion. There were 12 hour differences in our comms presuming time difference US to China. But they got the problem solved..and made me a happy owner confident that if any other issues arise on this - or any of their other products - that I will be supported. It appears that I am not alone in this opinion. Thanks to Soundcore.

As a med student, I was so excited to get these headphones without investing a ton of money. I absolutely love the rose color, the case they come with and how easy they are to use. They're lightweight so they don't weigh down my backpack, but as a full headset they do take up a fair bit of room so keep that in mind if you're planning to travel or pack them out to work/school every day. My only complaint is the inequality in noise cancelling between the R and L earpiece. My left ear piece has perfect noise cancelling quality, but the R earpiece will only cancel noises if it is directly perpendicular with the noise source. This gets annoying when I turn my head between my computer and iPad, and when I unconsciously cock my head to one side as I write. Overall, it's a great product and I still would buy them again for a first time set of noise cancelling headphones. I have always been aware that I'm really noise sensitive, and these headphones have really highlighted that since I bought them because I get such a sense of relief from wearing them - even with the disparity in noise cancellation between the ear pieces. Overall, 7/10 - I really recommend them!

I've been using these regularly for about 11 months now. Here's my take.Pros:- Comfortable. I can wear them for hours without any issues.- Decent sound quality, but only if you take the time to tune the equalizer.- Decent noise cancellation.- Great battery life.Cons:- The microphone isn't good enough. People will probably understand you, but the quality falls short. I'm too embarrassed to use them in a meeting with this level of quality.- The audio quality is not great unless you take the time to tune the equalizer. This shouldn't be necessary.- The wear detection is worse than useless. The headphones will randomly stop playback when I'm wearing the headphones. And when I take them off, it won't stop. Worthless. I had to disable the feature.- The power button drives me crazy. You have to press it for a long time (5 seconds) to turn it on or off. And, if you accidentally turn it off (because you didn't realize they were already on, or because they timed out and turned themselves off automatically), you can't turn them back on right away. There's a delay before you can turn them back on again. It drives me crazy. To the designers: A one-second delay is plenty to protect against accidental bumps, and there should not be a delay before I can turn them back on again.- These turn off automatically way too soon. If I put them down for what seems like a short time, when I come back they're off again. And it's not always obvious they're off, so sometimes I accidentally turn them off rather than on, which is frustrating because of the long power button delay mentioned above. The battery life is so good on these that there's no reason for them to turn off so aggressively.- You can't use them while charging. Sometimes, the battery runs low or runs out while I'm using them. It'd be great if I could plug them in while I'm still using them. They just stop working once I plug in the power cord.It's really too bad because I think the power button and auto power feature would be super easy to fix with a firmware update. Or why not make it configurable?

I have a lot of Anker products because they always work well. I use these exclusively for music and sometimes gaming. This is my first pair of noise canceling headphones so I may have expected more than I should. NC does work. It definitely reduces the sound from the home theater and even lessens the dogs barking. I would definitely recommend them as a low cost alternative to the $300+ models.

Ive only had them a week but set up was simple, they are comfortable and pretty easy to use. I do wish the noise canceling was a little better but im still happy with the purchase so far. Ill update if anything changes.

These are comfortable to wear, easy to use, but man, they stink. There is an awful smell on the ear covers. Is this the material? Did they send me a used an retuned pair? I’ll leave them out over night to see if the stink dissipates, if not, I guess they go back ?

I tried the Soundcore Q30, Q35, Sony 1000XM3 and Bose 700.Q30 & Q35 were the only ones that didn't have some kind of issue or problem complicating things immediately, and the Q30's were the only ones not instantly disappointing.Q35 seem to be Q30s with worse earpads, a little better ANC, a slightly more premium feel in general like the plastics, the carrying case and box it come in but much much worse transparency mode and an additional $50 price tag.I was primarily looking for the ones with the best transparency mode to be able to hear my kids and monitor the house at night while still listening to something privately.In the end the Bose 700 has the best transparency mode but too many other problem and extreme cost.The Bose 700 were the most disappointing.Literally had me saying outloud " $400 for this, is this a joke" as I struggled to get their terrible app to work with their headphones.The headphones linked to my phone as one device and thought the APP on the phone was a different device... I was literally googling Bose support pages with in 5 minutes of opening the very nice cardboard box to figure out how to reset the headphones device history  and re-pair them. Turned out to be easy to do but still infuriating, and took 3 tries before the APP managed the find the headphone anywhere near as quickly as the actual phone did and finally paired properly. The transparency mode is incredible but mostly I think because you can hear your own voice nearly perfectly so you don't have the 'inside a barrel" feel. But also there was a faint repeating crackle or pop sound that was very tolerable if not for the pricepoint. the sheer cost amplifies the negative feeling associated with every little flaw and unfortunately these 700s have multiple. Bose transparency is the best but it is absolutely NOT $320 better than the Q30s.The Q30 had the second best transparency mode and the worst anc of them but still really good anc. (As in I could still fainly hear the air conditioner sitting 3 feet away from me).Sony's 1000xm3 had the best ANC but worse transparency mode than the Q30, with the xm3s you can hear everything but you can't tell what direction anything is coming from, it's odd. Like your not hearing your surroundings but instead are hearing a fake recreation of your surroundings being played back to you. It's hard to describe, I only realized that was the problem after hearing a bird outside, with the xm3s I could hear a bird but had no idea what direction it was coming from but with the Q30 I could hear the bird immediately and what direction it was.Note: with the xm3s, if you buy the international version all the voice prompts will be in Chinese.The sound is an awful bassy mess on all of them but the Bose 700s unless you fix them with the EQ but thankfully they all have a decent EQ with the exception of the Bose which has a nearly worthless EQ with 3 sliders. Ironically the worst EQ is on the one that doesn't need one basically at all but is so expensive you'd expect the option.Bose EQ is very clearly an afterthought slapped onto the app in response to Sony having one and being the new King of ANC.Oh also of note the Q30 and Q35 have that unpleasant "new memory foam" smell right out of the box but it nearly immediately goes away. Perhaps they should have let them air out for a few minutes before immediately shipping them. It's something you'll probably notice but shrug it off and you'll forget it was a thing at all.TLDR; Buy the Q30s and wonder to yourself what how they are 80% as good as Bose 700s at 20% of the cost.If the absolutely need the very best ANC money can buy get the xm4s probably but everyone else should buy Q30.

I was extremely impressed with these cans. For $125 I'm happy. Battery lasts for days of constant use, fit perfect on my head, after breaking in they sound excellent, well made and the Soundcore App with EQ allows you to dial them in. I've had them for about a month and put 50-75hrs on them so far.

Got these during Prime Day and they were less than $100, pretty good deal. And I definitely fell for the beautiful obsidian blue radiance. They look and feel premium. I did extensive research from YouTube Videos to blog posts about comparison between Beats, Sony and Soundcore. The only shortcoming will be soundproof, you can still hear stuff with ANC but you can definitely tell it's a lot quieter and I use them in the office so it's good enough. Overall this is a great purchase. I have used them for about 2 weeks and still loving them.

These headphones worked really well, but for more than $100, I hoped to get more than 6 months before they snapped on me. There's no use in NC when the cups can't clamp over your ears anymore, due to the swivel snapping.

I got these based on the specs of 4 microphones and AI technology to help isolate my voice on calls.  They work extremely well indoors with minimal or no background noise, but I cannot use them when walking outside to talk on the phone.  I'm not talking a loud or windy environment, I mean just being outside my office building with no wind and no one else around.  That is disappointing to me since the specs make it seem like they are literally made for calls.  I also notice that the pause feature when you remove an ear cup only seems to work about 30% of the time.  This isn't terribly bothersome for me since I don't mind rewinding whatever I'm listening to, but it was an issue I saw in other reviews which is also an issue for me.All in all, I really enjoy the app which allows me to customize my listening equalizer/ music mode, the sound quality is great, the noise cancelling is great, and the comfort is great.  Unfortunately though, the added features that were supposed to make these the ideal product for me are lacking in the microphone pickup/ AI for calls, and the pause often does not initiate when I remove an ear cup or the headphones entirely.I personally don't think they are worth the money and would recommended going with an older model for less or a different brand all together.
Oh, I really like the product. Works well and very comfortable on my head. The problem that I have is with the instructions. The writing is so tiny one needs a bright light and a magnifying glass.

My initial impressions:  Comfortable and light weight.  Love the transparent feature and decent noise canceling.What I wish could be better:  the equalizer in the app is pretty limited, from 100Hz to 12KHz bands and only up to 6 db adjustment.  Would really like to see a wider equalizer, at the very least, 60Hz to 16KHz for finer control.Also, the vinyl cups can be overwhelmingly smelly as they are still curing from the manufacturing process.  These kind of smells could take a little while to disappear.update July 12 2021:  One thing I've noticed between the three modes (Noise Canceling, Transparency, Normal) is that in Transparency and Normal modes, the bass is drastically reduced.  I'm not sure why they designed it to do that but I love listening to music with low bass notes, so this is a little disappointing when I want to use Transparency mode.  However, in NC mode, the bass is amazing and really gets down on those bass notes when you have the source EQ set right.Advice on setting your EQ if you are on a Samsung phone:To get even more deeper bass and crispier highs, go into the Android Sound settings and look for the equalizer.  Instead of "pumping up" any of the EQ bars, bring DOWN the bars  instead.  This causes the the frequencies beyond the very ends to stay at near zero attenuation even if you don't see it on screen.  You'll hear the difference.  The android EQ is a little strange.Update January 2022:I continue enjoying the headphones.  My only real beef with them at this point is the cheap noisy plastic, especially in a quiet room.  I've woken up my significant other a few times in bed when I removed the headphones from my head to put them away.  Any kind of flexing and they can wake up the dead.
I wear these in public and love them. I walked by a diesel generator and didn't know it was there until I took my headphones off and walked back by it to grab lunch.

These things are GREAT, and I love them.  They do a pretty good job of noise cancellation (I use them primarily for drowning out noise in an open office environment), and the sound is awesome.  Finally some headphones that get loud!  The app is neat, but I do wish I could control the headphones with the app when it's connected to my work laptop for meetings.  I love the fast switching; they seem to pair with *everything* and it's super convenient to start a meeting without having to connect/disconnect.  I haven't used the transparency tap yet, but I can also say that the take off/pause and put on/play works great, and I love that.  I take them off to answer a question of a co-worker and don't miss but a few words of my podcast or audiobook.  Overall, these are great, super comfortable to wear for 8 hours or so a day, hold a great charge, and are very attractive.  I got the pink, and the color is subtle and soft, not jarring.  Soundcore/Anker makes great stuff, and I have a house full of their speakers, cables, and even bought their Eufy security system.  Everything is top notch and works like cake at a birthday party.  10/10 recommend!

I was disappointed in these. The sound was very good, but it didn't meet a standard that I had in mind. Two things were missing, 1. Staging.  The sound didn't seem to fill the the area around me with my eyes closed. 2. Bass wasn't nearly as predominant as I like my lows to be. I can see these phones being very acceptable for a lot of people. But when I spend the money and want to exercise, chill, listen to a podcast, I want the sound that I'm looking for, and these just didn't do it.
For about half of the best noise-cancelling headphones, you get about 80% of the way there with these. Great value.

First my bias.  I am a fan of Anker.  It is one Chinese company that builds quality innovative electrics at a very competitive price. This headset has great sound.  It can sound as good as the Bose for music, but with the added benefit of being able to adjust the sound better for different types of listening.  E.g., Bose has too much bass for speech, which is 90% of what I listen to.  The Anker Life Q35, can deliver the strong mellow bass sound of a Bose that I like for music, but it can be easily tuned to deliver clear speech, also.  Battery life is excellent.  I've never run out of power in any single day of use.  I charge overnight.  Aesthetics are good, IMO.  Materials and build quality seem good so far, only time will tell how durable any product is.  The firmware still needs some tweaking.  One firmware upgrade improved some of the issues I was experiencing.  Still, re-connecting to a device can be hit-and-miss.  It still occasionally disconnects for no apparently reason.  The on/off button takes a 4-5 second press to activate, why?  It won't connect to my Sony TV (It may be more of problem with the TV than the headset, who knows).  The headband needs a pad to help hold it in place.  Nevertheless, overall it a very good product, well worth the price.

I had just moved into a small condo/roommate situation which was in a busier area with lots of outside noise that I was not acustomed to.  When I first put them on and turned on the noise canceling mode for outdoor noise, I was blown away!  It's like I was on another planet.  Just me and whatever I wanted to stream through the headphones.  I love that the app has various white noise options to help me sleep and my phone calls through this product have been so clear!Above all though, I was blown away with the level of customer service and dedication this company puts forth on a daily basis. My second pair arrived within days with no issues and with all the same high-level of noise cancelling that I was loooking for.  I highly recommend one of the Ankler products if you have never tried.

These are just right tight enough to fit securely and and get a good seal around the ear. These work well with my iPhone, iPad and pc. I purchased those and immediately had problems. The wear sensor detection was wonky and I was experiencing LDAC sound quality issues. SoundCore sent me a replacement pair and it was the same issues. I reached out to their customer service and they sent me an LDAC from where update 1.18 and that fixed it. With that said... These headsets are the best on the market with the LDAC. Even if you don't want to customize you have 22 different presets that are excellent My personal favorite is acoustic and piano. I will admit that the sound core signature is a little low and the bass is pretty heavy but with that being said you have so many other choices That's not even relevant in my opinion. I love the different sound modes and listening to music or movies is now on another whole level. It's light enough to carry around and overall great value

The noise cancelling is very effective at removing noises in all of those environments. The headphones are comfortable to wear for long duration, and they have impressive battery life. I can't drain them even with all day use.

My only complaint is the feature that shuts off the headphones works poorly. Granted, I haven't talked to Soundcore yet because they do back their products. I purchased these headphones because of that. When I tilt my head to bend over they shut off. However if I pull them off and hang them around my neck they stay on. If I turn my music on pause they come back on. That feature was a major decision maker for me because I need to pull the headphones off and on for work. Other than that I love them. The software for the equalizer tweeks them to your desired sound quite well.

Extra bonus, they effectively drown out my co-workers’ hours of horrendous non stop off-key singing and butchering 90s hits on repeat. Work is actually bearable. Sound quality is great. Doesn’t feel cheap. I love the rose-goldish color.

These have surprisingly good ANC. When I compare them to my Sony WHXB900N, the ANC on these is actually quite a bit better, despite Sony being known for pretty good ANC. The ANC is not as good as an oldish Bose QC35II I have though. In the grand scheme of things, I'd rate the ANC at 8/10. Better than most other brands I've tried, held up well on my most recent flight.The comfort could use some work, though. The earpads are a little more stiff than competitors, owing to whatever foam they used I guess. The similarly priced WHXB900N are more comfortable, to me.The Anker app is good. Allows customizations that I want, and is far better than most of the other brands' apps for customizing headphones.A large complaint of mine comes from them attempting to copy the 'hold hand over earcup for quick attention mode transparency' thing from other brands. They did a poor job here, though one they could probably fix with a firmware update. If I do this gesture on my Sonys, the transparency mode comes on instantly basically as soon as my hand touches the earcup. On these, there's something like a 2 second delay, and a beep, and then transparency turns on. I feel like I'd have to tell whoever's trying to talk to me to just stand there and wait for a second while I wait for my headphones to catch up.

I must be doing something wrong, because I find the ANC and transparency almost nonexistent for most frequencies compared to TWS earbuds. Either that or I'm expecting too much from ANC on full size headphones (my first wireless full size).Otherwise, fantastic, flexible sound quality. Don't quite understand when they're dinged here. You can adjust them however YOU want in the app, then shut it down or even uninstall it - that 8 band EQ setting is stored in the headset. Then I pair to my Windows PC and fine tune EQ various media from there. This was my main purpose buying them and for that, very happy. Highly recommended unless ANC is your priority.

Great sound quality and comfort. The noise cancelling gives me a weird pressure on my ears which takes a second to get used to, then it does not give me issues. This is really cool, however if you move your head in a manner which slightly resembles the motion it will pause music and videos despite them still being on your head. I’ll look for Soundcore again when shopping for the next set, it’s an excellent value.

I know there are a mix of good and bad reviews out there and I have read them all. I'll start with the pros overall excellent sound quality very crisp and clear. The noise-cancelling is phenomenal, with multiple modes including a transparency mode so you can hear what's going on around you through the little microphones. The battery life is amazing it lasted for weeks using it multiple hours per day on the factory charge out of the box. It charged relatively quickly too full and I've been using it for a few weeks now regularly oh, and it is only down to about 60% battery life. The headphones are extremely comfortable to wear I haven't noticed any issues with them being too tight or even too hot like many others have said they're actually quite cool.The only con I found in common with other people is the change in sound profile when toggling between normal mode and noise cancelling. There is a significant increase in base in normal mode vs in noise-canceling but I have experience that with other headphones at higher price points so I don't know why people are complaining so intently about this particular quirk. I will say that the app allows for very easy correction of this issue as you can store multiple custom EQ presets tailored to your liking. You simply save a preset that compensates for the bass increase in normal mode and switch to that when you turn off the ANC. For headphones under the $200 price point these are extremely impressive. As far as longevity I cannot speak to how long they will last but I've had good luck with other soundcore products so I'm hopeful that they will give me a few good years.

I loved the Q20, but these headphones far exceeded my expectations and are incredible value for the price. Buy buy buy!
Overall I love the Soundcore Q35 but I just really wish that it had higher volume settings and more bass.
