Update:After some research, I found that I can reset the headset to factory defaults, so I though that I'd give that a try, after the factory reset the headset works as expected, the sounds not bad for a wireless headset,Not sure I care for the On/Off chime (seems to be the same), and should just say On or Off.Anyway, No more disconnect or Popping for now, but cannot recommend for a buy until I've used them awhile and the problems I've had don't reoccur.I purchased the headset because using earbuds don't block out any outside noise while mowing the yard, the headphones are better in that respect but not great.Just received my Q35 headset today, made sure it had a full charge before trying them out, Paired the headset to my Sony NW-A55 Walkman MP3 Player, the music sounds Ok, but the headset kept dropping the signal, popping then picking the signal back up;so, I tried pairing the headset to my computer, the same issue, the signal/music would drop then pop and pick the signal back up.I have a set of Bluetooth earbuds that works perfectly, I just wanted a headset to help cut out some outside noise, almost purchased a less expansive headset, guess I'll get them ordered.Unless I received a defective pair, I cannot recommend this product.

I guess I don't fit the main demographic of headphone users. I have some older wireless earbuds for when I'm out, they have served me well for a long time and I easily stuff them in the trucks center console. I like full over the ear headphones when I'm at home and listen to music Bluetooth streamed from my PC, Laptop, or TV, whichever one I'm using at the moment. I think this is the problem.I picked up a pair of over the ear headphones from Amazon a year or 2 back called Tribit. Very affordable and were prolly $40 at the time. The sounds always been good, but then someone turned me onto the Dolby Access app that works with Bluetooth headphones. Game changer! The cheap headphones suddenly got crisper, clearer and thumped hard enough at full volume, they would hurt by ears.This year I decided to treat myself to some more expensive headphones and ALMOST picked up the fancy Sony's when Amazon had them $100 off for Black Friday. Then after seeing reviews, these Life Q35's seemed to hold their own and, in some cases, reviewers rated them higher than the Mack Daddy Sony's. Decided to buy them and from all reviews, was really excited. I just got them in today and was TRULY expecting to be blown away... I am not.I think the problem is, no Windows 11 app. Anker Life Q35's have an iPhone app, but nothing for PC. On my phone, I can tweak and bend the sound, but not to any point that sounds better than the cheap Tribit's with a $10 Dolby Access app for Windows.These Life Q34's do have the bells and whistles, but I can't justify it. Active Noise Cancellation isn't something I need since I'm at home when I use the big headphones.It's nice to simply take off the headphones to pause and resume BUT, if I'm taking them on and off and have them in hand, I can just bump the power button and these pause and play.When connected to my Laptop with no Life Q35 app AND no Dolby Access app running, the Life Q35's do sound better, but not immensely. Not $80 better, not even $10 better. So, I come back to an app and for PC, that's Dolby Access because Anker Life Q35 doesn't offer one for PC. When I use that, which is the PC equivalent to the Life Q35 app... they lose and they lose badly. Bass heavy and muddy in the middle. I'm no audiophile by any means, but it's clearly a difference that's NOT in favor of the Q35's.These headphones really make me think about hardware versus software. How can an older set of cheaper headphones sound as good? If you need the NFC connecting, ANC system, fast charging, don't have the dexterity to bump a button for pause and play and exclusively use your cellphone for music, these would make excellent headphones for you. As for me, I will be returning them. I don't need the added features and there isn't $140 (tax included) worth of sound or product for me.

I bought these headphones on a whim because they were the Amazon deal of the day.  Only in the last couple of years did I adopt wireless tech, having been my whole adult life a big advocate for wired headphones and ear buds.  However, I feel technology has finally caught up to satisfy mid-level audiophiles such as myself.  For 100 dollars, these headphones deliver.  I use them mostly for music listening while doing chores, but recently used them on multiple cross-country flights and they worked splendidly.  My one complaint is there is no holistic solution for noise cancelation.  Anker likes to give you multiple options to block out specific ranges of sound.  I would like it if they'd just give an option to block out everything.  But sound quality is excellent especially for the price, battery life is phenomenal, comfort level is unbelievable (I wear them for hours with no discomfort), they get plenty loud if that's a concern of yours, and they sound great for all assortments of music. After speaking with 3 different people they've all wanted to know why I was sounding like I was in a can. I confirmed the issue myself as well. Resetting the headphones, re-pairing Bluetooth, reinstalling app, restarting phone and headphones etc did not help improve mic quality.The headphones also have a high amount of sound leak as well. So they won't be good for discrete listening. People could clearly hear the lyrics and instrumentals of the music I was listening to at about 80% volume from at least 6 ft away in a quiet room.I will be returning these but will recommend for those who don't need headphones for calls but want decent sound quality, good battery life and easy to use controls at a decent price point.

The Features are an improvement over the life q30, the mic quality is better, the on/off detection works really well and the addition of LDAC codec is a nice touch. But that’s as far it goes when it comes to pros over the life q30. If your a bass head you’re going to love this headphone it has a lot of bass out of the box(way to much in my opinion) Even with eq you can’t get rid of the boosted sub bass and mid bass making it bleed into the other frequencies. Is fair to mention that the eq makes this a better sounding headphone, but not better than the life q30. The life q 30 are “bassy” out of the box as well, but not as much as the life q35. The comfort, the life q35 have different pads they feel more high quality when it comes to the memory foam, but for some reason in my case my ears start going hotter quicker and that boosted sub bass rattles my head to no end making this headphone not very comfortable for long listening sections. The ANC is the same as the life q30 so no improvement there to my ears. So in conclusion if you like detail and more clarity on your mids and highs go for the cheaper option(with eq) if you like bass and the extra features go with the life q35. Hope this helps!

The good:-These sounded pretty great once you create a flat profile.-They were overwhelmingly bass heavy initially.-Once tweaked, the sound quality was great when setting this up through my PC or android phone.-Build quality was spot on. The padding is great on the top and the headphones padding feels comfortable if you have small ears.The Bad:-The fit is too tight. I'd consider my ears average size, but the tips of my ears hit the inside of the cans making these hurt after about an hour.-Heavy, these cans weigh a lot more then previous wireless headphones.-Transparency mode annoying. I kept activating it on accident since any little press towards the right headphone turns it on or off.-Mic quality. The mic had a max bitrate of 16khz at one channel. I haven't seen number that low since the 90s! It is 2022, there is no reason for a microphone to have a bitrate that low for making a call or voice chatting.-Not Full Duplex. I bought these to replace an uncomfortable and lackluster pair of wired "gaming" headphones from a company I had high respect for. Comparatively speaking, audio quality is amazing for music and light/mmo gaming. I don't play FPS, so I can't comment on that. I didn't notice any audio lag from my PC, even when dual-paired between my phone and PC. There was a bit of audio lag when playing a mobile game, but switching from LDAC to AAC in the Bluetooth settings cleared that up. App has amazing EQ customization and the LDAC takes advantage of it. I'm still working through the break-in period, so I can only expect them to get better. ANC is nice, but I feel like the Life Pro 2 earbuds do it better. Definitely not to the level of a good/expensive set of Sony or Bose, but you get what you pay for. It will be sufficient for home-office working (I can't hear fans/PC/dog with ANC on and music playing) or traveling.A really neat feature is the customizable white-noise system in the app. I had it set to sound like a stormy night at the beach. Had some good memories come back. :)So far, for the price, these are excellent Bluetooth cans. I'm very satisfied and happy with them.That being said, if you're not concerned with having LDAC or a few other features, the Life Q30 is almost half the price. Definitely compare the two. Personally, I felt the features justified the price.

Great sound, love the presets, great battery life, but two caveats…1. Whatever LDAC does (I’m no audiophile), it doesn’t do it on an iPhone or iPad. Apple does not support the LDAC codec. LDAC is one of the advertised upgrade benefits of the Q35 over the Q30. This was never mentioned in any Anker ad copy that I saw. Only one online reviewer mentioned it in passing. Sorry Apple fans.2. The auto-pause “feature” is flaky. It would unceremoniously freeze my videos and audios with no provocation whatsoever. After 2 returns to Anker (great customer service BTW) I finally found how to disable it in the Soundcore app: turn on your Q35s and make sure they are paired to your mobile device. Wait for the app to “discover” your Q35s. Then tap the Settings gear icon upper right. Move the “Wearing Detection” slider to the left to disable this “feature”. After I did this, the headphones are rock solid. It took me way longer to figure this out than it should have.Despite the issues above these are excellent headphones, I’m keeping mine. A happy iPhone user!
